user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_init_page_sizes:
```c
static int metal_init_page_sizes(void)
{
	const int max_sizes = MAX_PAGE_SIZES - 1;
	long sizes[max_sizes];

	/* Determine system page size. */
	sizes[0] = getpagesize();
	if (sizes[0] <= 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "failed to get page size\n");
		return -EINVAL;
	}
	_metal.page_size  = sizes[0];
	_metal.page_shift = metal_log2(sizes[0]);
	metal_add_page_size(_metal.tmp_path, _metal.page_shift, 0);

#ifdef HAVE_HUGETLBFS_H
#ifndef MAP_HUGE_SHIFT
	/* System does not support multiple huge page sizes. */
	sizes[0] = gethugepagesize();
	if (sizes[0] > 0) {
		metal_add_page_size(hugetlbfs_find_path(),
				    metal_log2(sizes[0]),
				    MAP_HUGETLB);
	}
#else
	if (gethugepagesize() >= 0) {
		int i, count;

		/* System supports multiple huge page sizes. */
		count = gethugepagesizes(sizes, max_sizes);
		for (i = 0; i < count; i++) {
			int shift = metal_log2(sizes[i]);

			if ((shift & MAP_HUGE_MASK) != shift)
				continue;
			metal_add_page_size(
				hugetlbfs_find_path_for_size(sizes[i]),
				shift, (MAP_HUGETLB |
				(shift << MAP_HUGE_SHIFT)));
		}
	}
#endif
#endif

	/* Finally sort the resulting array by size. */
	qsort(_metal.page_sizes, _metal.num_page_sizes,
	      sizeof(struct metal_page_size), metal_pagesize_compare);

	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_init_page_sizes:
#define MAX_PAGE_SIZES 32
...
#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__);\
})
...
static int metal_pagesize_compare(const void *_a, const void *_b)
{
	const struct metal_page_size *a = _a, *b = _b;
	long diff = a->page_size - b->page_size;

	return metal_sign(diff);
}
...
struct metal_page_size {
	/** Page size. */
	size_t	page_size;

	/** Page shift. */
	unsigned long page_shift;

	/** Path to hugetlbfs (or tmpfs) mount point. */
	char path[PATH_MAX];

	/** Flags to use for mmap. */
	int mmap_flags;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I selected fragments that may contain code that is never reached or that depend on compile-time configuration and platform behavior (they need investigation to determine if any statements are in fact unreachable at runtime or by configuration). Specifically I included: the getpagesize() error check (which may be redundant or impossible on target platforms), the entire HAVE_HUGETLBFS_H region and its two alternative branches (the code inside these preprocessor branches may be compiled out or may contain inner conditions that never hold), the single-size hugepage branch (gethugepagesize() usage), the multi-size hugepage branch (gethugepagesize() >= 0 guard, gethugepagesizes loop), the masking test ((shift & MAP_HUGE_MASK) != shift) and the metal_add_page_size() call that shifts by MAP_HUGE_SHIFT. These fragments cover all places where control flow might never reach the inner statements due to platform APIs, preprocessor configuration, or bit-mask conditions.

Why other fragments are not included: the straightforward initial assignments (_metal.page_size/_metal.page_shift), the unconditional metal_add_page_size(_metal.tmp_path, ...), the qsort call and final return 0 are ordinary, reachable code paths in normal execution and do not on their face present unreachable statements. The macro definition and helper functions in the additional code were not selected because they do not themselves contain obviously unreachable statements in the provided snippets. If investigation shows any of the selected fragments are reachable on the intended platforms/configurations, then no further fragments in this function appear to violate MISRA C Rule 2.1.
